title: Breakthrough Seizure (Known Epilepsy)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of breakthrough seizures in adults with known epilepsy who are on established antiseizure medication (ASM) regimens. Covers identification of precipitants, medication level assessment, adjustment strategies, and evaluation for secondary causes. Excludes new-onset seizure (separate workup), status epilepticus (see SE template), and non-epileptic events (psychogenic non-epileptic seizures).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **CRITICAL**: Subtherapeutic levels are #1 cause of breakthrough seizures; check ALL ASMs with available assays
Essential/Core Labs.target: Therapeutic ranges (see Appendix); subtherapeutic = adjust dose or assess adherence

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection as precipitant; baseline for ASM hematologic effects; thrombocytopenia (valproate)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis → infection workup; low platelets → consider valproate toxicity

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia common with carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine); renal function (affects ASM dosing); hepatic function (ASM metabolism, toxicity); glucose (hypoglycemia as seizure cause)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia <130 mEq/L can provoke seizures; elevated LFTs → ASM hepatotoxicity

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia is reversible seizure cause; hyperglycemia (DKA) can also cause seizures
Hyponatremia: carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine cause SIADH; <125-130 mEq/L can provoke seizures
Essential/Core Labs.target: 135-145 mEq/L; <130 → correct slowly (risk of osmotic demyelination)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypocalcemia can cause seizures; also check if hypocalcemic tetany suspected
Hypomagnesemia lowers seizure threshold; chronic ASM use may deplete Mg
UTI is common occult infection that provokes seizures, especially in elderly
Illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines) can provoke seizures; drug interactions with ASMs; adherence assessment
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive → specific drug-related seizure risk assessment

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Alcohol withdrawal seizures; intoxication; binge drinking
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative or low; elevated or history of recent heavy use → alcohol withdrawal protocol

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pregnancy affects ASM levels (increased clearance, volume distribution); teratogenicity concerns; seizure risk in pregnancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Document result; if positive → urgent neurology/OB consultation; ASM teratogenicity counseling

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: For highly protein-bound drugs (phenytoin, valproate) in patients with hypoalbuminemia, renal failure, pregnancy, or polypharmacy; free level is the active fraction
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Free phenytoin: 1-2 mcg/mL; free valproate: 5-15 mcg/mL; adjusted interpretation based on clinical context

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Valproate-induced hyperammonemic encephalopathy (can occur with normal LFTs); confusion/lethargy post-ictal vs. encephalopathy
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <35 μmol/L; elevated → valproate toxicity; consider discontinuation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Post-ictal lactate elevation (typically resolves within 2h); persistent elevation may indicate status epilepticus or alternative cause
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Mildly elevated post-ictal (normalizes quickly); persistent elevation concerning

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Elevated 10-20 min post-seizure (2-3x baseline); helps distinguish epileptic seizure from psychogenic non-epileptic seizure (PNES); must be drawn within 20 min
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: 2-3x baseline within 20 min of convulsive seizure; normal in PNES

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can affect seizure threshold and ASM metabolism
Adrenal insufficiency; chronic ASM use (enzyme inducers) may affect cortisol
Phenytoin and carbamazepine can deplete folate; B12 deficiency neuropathy; pregnancy planning
Enzyme-inducing ASMs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital) increase vitamin D metabolism → osteoporosis risk

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: HLA-B*15:02 (carbamazepine/SJS risk in Asian populations); HLA-A*31:01 (carbamazepine hypersensitivity in Europeans); before starting new ASMs
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative for risk alleles; positive → avoid associated ASM

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Active metabolite of carbamazepine; may be elevated when total level appears therapeutic (especially with inhibitors like valproate); correlates with toxicity
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: <9 mcg/mL; elevated → toxicity even with normal carbamazepine level

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If new seizure semiology, cognitive decline, or refractory seizures in previously controlled patient; autoimmune etiology
If infection, autoimmune encephalitis, or CNS malignancy suspected as new cause
If genetic cause suspected (family history, syndromic features, drug-resistant epilepsy); may guide ASM selection
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Specific mutations (SCN1A, SCN2A, KCNQ2, etc.) may inform treatment choices (e.g., avoid sodium channel blockers in Dravet syndrome)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: NOT routinely indicated for uncomplicated breakthrough seizure; **INDICATED if:** Suspected meningitis/encephalitis (fever, meningismus, altered mentation beyond typical post-ictal); suspected autoimmune encephalitis; immunocompromised patient with seizure
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in uncomplicated breakthrough; pleocytosis → infection or autoimmune; elevated protein; specific antibodies
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Mass lesion with mass effect; coagulopathy

Essential/First-line.timing: **NOT routinely needed** for uncomplicated breakthrough seizure in known epilepsy with return to baseline; **INDICATED if:** Head trauma (fall during seizure), prolonged post-ictal state (>30 min), focal neurologic deficit, new seizure semiology, anticoagulation, fever + seizure, first seizure at this facility
Essential/First-line.target: Acute hemorrhage; mass lesion; edema; hydrocephalus; prior surgical changes
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None (for non-contrast); pregnancy (benefit outweighs minimal risk)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: **NOT acutely needed** if stable known epilepsy with unchanged seizures; **INDICATED if:** Change in seizure semiology, increased seizure frequency without clear precipitant, new focal deficit, concern for progressive lesion, presurgical evaluation
Essential/First-line.target: Tumor; mesial temporal sclerosis; cortical dysplasia; vascular malformation; new structural cause
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; VNS devices (check MRI compatibility of specific device)

Essential/First-line.timing: Post-ictal arrhythmia; syncope vs. seizure; QTc prolongation (some ASMs); baseline for ASM changes
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; arrhythmia may indicate cardiac cause; prolonged QTc (avoid QT-prolonging ASMs)

Extended.timing: Within 24-48h if possible (higher yield closer to seizure); characterize epileptiform activity; confirm epileptic vs. non-epileptic; guide ASM choice; localization
Extended.target: Epileptiform discharges (spikes, sharp waves); focal vs. generalized; specific epilepsy syndrome features

Extended.timing: **INDICATED if:** Prolonged or fluctuating alteration of consciousness; concern for nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE); ICU patient with unexplained encephalopathy; frequent seizures
Extended.target: Ictal patterns; NCSE; interictal epileptiform activity; quantify seizure burden

Extended.timing: Capture typical events if infrequent; home monitoring for 24-72h or longer
Extended.target: Ictal events; interictal discharges; seizure frequency

Extended.timing: Characterize events if diagnostic uncertainty (epileptic vs. PNES); presurgical evaluation; medication taper for surgery
Extended.target: Ictal semiology; EEG correlation; localization for surgery

Extended.timing: Aspiration pneumonia (common post-ictal complication); ETT position if intubated

Rare/Advanced.timing: High-resolution imaging for epileptogenic lesion identification; 3T preferred; includes thin-cut coronal T2/FLAIR through temporal lobes
Rare/Advanced.target: Mesial temporal sclerosis; focal cortical dysplasia; cavernous malformation; low-grade tumor

Rare/Advanced.timing: Presurgical localization; hypometabolism (interictal PET) or hyperperfusion (ictal SPECT) at seizure focus
Presurgical localization; dipole source analysis; specialized centers
Presurgical evaluation; cognitive baseline; localization (memory lateralization for temporal lobe epilepsy)
Rare/Advanced.target: Lateralized deficits; cognitive baseline for surgery comparison

dosing.instructions: **Lorazepam** 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg), may repeat x1 in 5 min; **OR Midazolam** 10 mg IM (if no IV access); **OR Diazepam** 0.2 mg/kg IV (max 10 mg); **Intranasal midazolam** 5-10 mg if no IV; **Rectal diazepam** 0.2-0.5 mg/kg (home rescue)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: First-line for acute seizure termination; lorazepam preferred IV (longer CNS duration); follow status epilepticus protocol if seizure continues >5 min

dosing.instructions: Clear environment of hazards; DO NOT restrain or put anything in mouth; turn on side (recovery position) when safe; suction secretions; monitor airway; time the seizure

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Prevent injury; prepare for airway management if prolonged

dosing.instructions: Recovery position; monitor airway (aspiration risk); supplemental O2 if SpO2 <92%; assess for injuries (tongue laceration, shoulder dislocation, vertebral fracture); reassurance; reorientation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Post-ictal period is self-limited (typically 5-30 min); prolonged alteration → consider NCSE, repeat seizure, or alternative diagnosis

dosing.instructions: If patient missed doses → give maintenance ASM immediately; if patient does not have medication with them → administer from ED/hospital supply

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Non-adherence is most common cause of breakthrough seizure; restoring therapeutic levels is priority

dosing.instructions: **Phenytoin/Fosphenytoin:** 15-20 mg PE/kg IV (if level very low); **Valproate:** 20-30 mg/kg IV (if level very low); **Levetiracetam:** 1000-1500 mg IV (if not on levetiracetam — can be added); **Note:** Loading the same drug patient is already taking risks toxicity → use cautiously

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: For significantly subtherapeutic levels or if need rapid therapeutic concentration; adjust for partial levels

dosing.instructions: **Infection:** Antibiotics for UTI, pneumonia; **Electrolyte abnormality:** Correct (hyponatremia slowly); **Drug/alcohol withdrawal:** Appropriate protocol; **Sleep deprivation:** Education, sleep hygiene

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Treating the precipitant may be more important than adjusting ASMs

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Resume current regimen at prescribed doses
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Non-adherence is #1 cause; restoring regimen usually sufficient

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Increase current ASM OR add second ASM
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Some patients require levels above "therapeutic range" for control

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Add second ASM OR optimize current ASM timing
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Breakthrough at therapeutic levels may require adjunctive therapy

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Remove interacting drug OR increase ASM dose OR switch ASM
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Enzyme inducers and inhibitors significantly affect ASM levels
Seizure risk to mother and fetus outweighs small ASM risk; maintain control
Change in control pattern requires investigation for new etiology

Specific ASM Adjustments.adjustment notes: Nonlinear kinetics; small dose changes → large level changes; check free level if hypoalbuminemia, renal failure, pregnancy; adjust dose by 25-50 mg increments
Auto-induction over 2-4 weeks (levels drop); check 4 weeks after initiation; also check epoxide level if toxicity suspected
Highly protein-bound; check free level in elderly, hepatic disease, pregnancy; check ammonia if encephalopathy
Level: 12-46 mcg/mL often cited; renal dosing required; generally well-tolerated dose increases
Highly affected by enzyme inducers (carbamazepine, phenytoin, oral contraceptives) and inhibitors (valproate); pregnancy increases clearance; slow titration to avoid rash
Causes hyponatremia (check sodium); less drug interactions than carbamazepine
Check ECG (PR prolongation); dose-dependent side effects; no major drug interactions
Renal dosing; causes metabolic acidosis, cognitive effects, kidney stones; enzyme inducer reduces OCP efficacy
Long half-life (adjust weekly); sedation; enzyme inducer
Similar to levetiracetam but may have fewer behavioral side effects; can substitute directly for levetiracetam
Benzodiazepine; tolerance may develop; useful adjunct especially in Lennox-Gastaut

Non-Pharmacologic Considerations.details: Padded side rails; suction at bedside; no sharps within reach; fall risk protocol; 1:1 supervision if frequent seizures
State-specific laws; generally 3-12 months seizure-free required; document counseling; patient should NOT drive until cleared
Avoid swimming alone; no heights (ladders, scaffolding); avoid dangerous machinery; bathing vs. showers (supervision if frequent seizures)
Sleep deprivation is major trigger; regular sleep schedule; 7-8 hours nightly; avoid shift work if possible
Alcohol lowers seizure threshold; withdrawal is high risk; cocaine/amphetamines provoke seizures; counsel strongly
Stress/anxiety are common triggers; counseling; mindfulness; adequate support
If patient has VNS → check device function; consider adjusting parameters; use magnet during seizure if trained
Ensure compliance; check ketosis; dietary counseling
If drug-resistant epilepsy (failure of 2 appropriate ASMs at adequate doses) → refer for surgical evaluation

differential.features: Typical semiology for patient; post-ictal state; EEG correlation; identifiable precipitant or subtherapeutic level
differential.tests: ASM levels; EEG; precipitant search

differential.features: Variable semiology; prolonged duration (>2 min); preserved awareness with bilateral movements; eyes closed; pelvic thrusting; ictal crying; side-to-side head movements; no post-ictal confusion (or prolonged pseudo-post-ictal); normal prolactin; normal EEG during event
differential.tests: Video-EEG (gold standard); prolactin (not elevated); clinical features; psychology evaluation

differential.features: Triggered by standing, hot environment, vagal stimulus; brief LOC (<1 min); myoclonic jerks are common during syncope (not true seizure); rapid recovery; pale before event
differential.tests: ECG; orthostatics; tilt table test; echocardiogram; cardiac history

differential.features: Sudden LOC without warning or with palpitations; rapid recovery; history of cardiac disease
differential.tests: ECG; Holter/event monitor; echocardiogram; electrophysiology study

differential.features: Hypoglycemia; hyponatremia; hypocalcemia; uremia; hepatic encephalopathy; drug intoxication/withdrawal
differential.tests: Glucose; electrolytes; renal/hepatic function; drug screen; specific toxin levels

differential.features: Negative symptoms (weakness, numbness, aphasia) vs. positive symptoms (convulsion); typically no LOC; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRI with DWI; MRA; vascular risk factor assessment

differential.features: REM sleep behavior disorder; parasomnias; cataplexy (narcolepsy)
differential.tests: Sleep history; PSG; MSL

differential.features: Dystonia; chorea; myoclonus (non-epileptic); paroxysmal dyskinesia
differential.tests: Preserved awareness; stereotyped movements; neurologic exam; movement disorder evaluation

differential.features: Visual, sensory, or motor aura preceding headache; duration 20-60 min; no LOC
differential.tests: Headache history; migraine features; may have EEG abnormalities but distinct from seizure

differential.features: Subtherapeutic ASM levels
differential.tests: Ask directly; check levels; pharmacy refill records; address barriers

differential.features: Lowers seizure threshold significantly
differential.tests: Sleep hygiene counseling; regular schedule; treat sleep disorders

differential.features: Fever lowers seizure threshold; metabolic stress
differential.tests: UA/culture; CXR; treat infection

differential.features: Both intoxication and withdrawal provoke seizures
differential.tests: Alcohol level; history; withdrawal prophylaxis

differential.features: Drug interactions; started medication that lowers threshold
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; check levels; review interactions

differential.features: Hyperexcitability
differential.tests: Stress management; counseling; anxiolytics if appropriate

differential.features: Perimenstrual or periovulatory clustering
differential.tests: Seizure diary correlation; hormonal treatment; increase ASM perimenstrually

differential.features: Hyponatremia (carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine); hypocalcemia; hypomagnesemia
differential.tests: Electrolyte panel; correct abnormality

differential.features: Cocaine, amphetamines lower seizure threshold
differential.tests: Drug screen; counseling

differential.features: Photic stimulation triggers seizures in photosensitive epilepsy
differential.tests: EEG with photic stimulation; avoid triggers; blue-tinted lenses

differential.features: New structural lesion (tumor, stroke, hemorrhage)
differential.tests: STAT imaging (CT then MRI)

differential.features: Status epilepticus; NCSE; structural lesion; metabolic cause; postictal paralysis (Todd's)
differential.tests: Continuous EEG; imaging; extended metabolic workup

differential.features: Meningitis/encephalitis; febrile seizure in adult is concerning
differential.tests: LP if meningitis suspected; imaging; antibiotics/antivirals empirically if indicated

differential.features: New epileptogenic lesion; different seizure type; PNES
differential.tests: EEG; MRI; video-EEG if needed

differential.features: Ongoing NCSE; structural lesion; metabolic encephalopathy
differential.tests: Continuous EEG; imaging; metabolic workup

differential.features: May not be known epilepsy; needs full new-onset seizure workup
differential.tests: Full workup unless confirmed prior epilepsy

differential.features: PNES (epileptic seizures typically have eyes open)
differential.tests: Video-EEG; psychology referral

differential.features: Status epilepticus; PNES (epileptic seizures typically <2-3 min)
differential.tests: Treat as SE if epileptic; video-EEG for characterization

evidence.recommendation: Practice Guideline Update: Efficacy and Tolerability of ASMs

evidence.evidenceLevel: 47% of newly diagnosed epilepsy patients became seizure-free on first ASM; 13% on second; 4% on third; after failure of 2 appropriate ASMs, chance of seizure freedom with additional ASMs is <5%
evidence.source: Defined drug-resistant epilepsy; established rationale for early surgery referral

evidence.evidenceLevel: Lamotrigine best for focal epilepsy; valproate best for generalized/unclassified (but teratogenic); levetiracetam non-inferior to lamotrigine for focal
evidence.source: Guide first-line ASM selection by seizure type

evidence.recommendation: Standard and New Antiepileptic Drugs (SNAED) Trial
evidence.evidenceLevel: Levetiracetam and zonisamide non-inferior to lamotrigine for focal epilepsy
Early surgery superior to continued medical therapy for drug-resistant temporal lobe epilepsy; 73% vs. 0% seizure-free at 2 years
evidence.source: Surgery is highly effective; early referral improves outcomes

evidence.evidenceLevel: Convulsive seizures, especially nocturnal; living alone; poor seizure control
evidence.source: Counsel patients; nocturnal monitoring devices; optimize seizure control

Q6-12 months or per ASM-specific monitoring

Prolonged post-ictal state; multiple seizures in ED; significantly subtherapeutic levels requiring monitoring during adjustment; uncertain diagnosis; new focal deficit; complicating medical illness

Single uncomplicated breakthrough seizure; returned to baseline; identifiable/correctable precipitant; therapeutic or corrected ASM level; no injuries requiring admission; safe home environment; reliable follow-up
Normal mental status and neurologic exam matching patient's baseline
Seizure-free since treatment/observation; no concern for subclinical seizures
Infection treated; missed doses restored; electrolytes corrected; adherence barriers addressed
Levels checked; dose adjustments made if indicated; supply of medications ensured
Driving restrictions documented; activity precautions; seizure first aid for caregivers; when to return
Neurology follow-up within 1-4 weeks; PCP as needed; EEG scheduled if indicated
Rectal diazepam or intranasal midazolam prescription if appropriate (cluster seizures, prolonged seizures)
Ensure supply of all ASMs; no gaps in medication
Dose, frequency, timing; what to do if dose missed; common side effects
Document state-specific requirement (typically 3-12 months seizure-free); document counseling
No swimming alone; no heights; supervision during bathing if frequent seizures; work restrictions if applicable
Prescription and training for rectal diazepam or intranasal midazolam
Education for patient and family; recovery position; when to call 911
Return for: repeat seizure, prolonged seizure, status epilepticus, new symptoms, fever with seizure, head injury
Neurology appointment; EEG if scheduled; PCP follow-up
Encourage bracelet/necklace for epilepsy identification
Provide or recommend app; track seizures, ASMs, triggers
